anonymised: OK great! Hello....so, just for a bit of background...are you planning to do the IELTS excam soon?
i have to do IELTS exam in april
OK right - are you planning to go to univeristy in the UK?
not in the UK, but it'll be in English lenguage
Right I see - so, in ITaly (?) but a course in English - is that a first degree or a master's? And what subject by the way?
medicine, but in Italy the entrance text is impossible to pass, so maybe I'll study genomics
Oh right - there's lots of work in that area here in CAmbridge you know that right?!
I know that in Cambridge you must have taken the highest mark in the maturity exam
do you mean it's hard to get into Cambridge University?
And do you mean the exams you do at the end of secondary school?
no, I mean in Italy when you finish the high school, you have to do an important exam, and I know that to get into Cambridge university you had to take 100\100
if you want to study medicine
Well in the UK you know that when you're 16 you have to choose 'A' level sybjects (usually 3) and the results for these determine your chances of getting into a particular university
so if you get an 'a' grade it's like 10 points etc and for e.g. Cambridge you basically need an A in all of your 'A' levels
So I imagine that you need top marks in the equivalent Italian qualification
also if I'm not English person?
if you did 'A' levels yes but the equivalent if not
by the way can you change the verb to something else in the phrase 'take high marks'?
yes possible, good! (NOT 'take'!) 'get' is the most common verb
and therefore e.g. 'get' 10 out of 10/get a B etc
get a high score etc etc
OK <STUDENT> so if you don't mind I'll start asking you questions based on the pie charts OK?
OK great so....can you write s sentence describing ONLY the following: Australia 1980 coal
As in NOT about change over time or France or any other fuel JUST those items OK?
Take a minute if you need it!
Think about the subject of the charts overall
the coal production was 50% in Australia in 1980
OK thanks a lot <STUDENT>...wait a sec
you've got past simple verb = good
one question: are the charts about coal production????
in this case, I can't use the verb halve?
ah! Can you ask my question first??
OK no problem hold on a sec
I ask me the same question when I wrote the sentence
well...If you begin with e.g. Australia....can you continue from here?
you need a verb next obviously so 'Australia....'?
OK nearly...! Did Australia 'use' electricity? well obviously yes but what about coal?
OK thanks <STUDENT> - let's try it together a bit more....hold on
So it's not a percentage of coal you see?
it's a percentage of ELECTRICITY from different fuels
OK great! Can you try a different way of giving the same information e.g. Australia coal 1980 but this time starting with the number e.g. 50 units...
50 units of electricity are produced by Australians from the use of coal
Yes good well done! hold on
so passive great yes but let's keep it in the past simple so...'were produced from'
what about beginning with the word 'coal'?!
so same information but different first word!
coal was used by Australian people to produce 50% of electricity
yes that's very good <STUDENT>! hold on
so I don't know if you've  done this before...do you know the verb 'account for'?
ah! no, it's not the same... Ok well, when we have a proportion of a total (i.e. with pie charts) we can use it so....e.g. 'Coal accounted for...'
I can't explain the meaning but in Italian it is a very similar word so I know the meaning ahah
So...'Coal accounted for 50% of electricity production in Australia in 1980.'
yes I  know what you mean about the Italian!
You can also the verb 'make up'  - hold on
in your morning class how many students are there more or less?
ok and how many male students?
OK so can you tell me that with the verb  'account for' and the word 'majority' for the proportion??
you OK? Begin with the word 'males' - does that help?
male students account for the majority of my morning class
So the total/title/subject  in a pie chart would be e.g. 'Students' so...the small category first e.g. Males followed by the account for followed by the total - OK?
One last test: use the same structure to tell me about France Oil 1980 OK? A full sentence!
oil accounted for 20% of electricity production in France in 1980
You'd get a good score with that language
One last thing before we finish...
So yuo can give the percentage = good but it's also good if you use other words to EXPLAIN what it means so e.g. can you say 'In 1980 coal was big in Australia'? is big the right word?
OK thanks good idea - but is it??
OK yes good half - that's good if you use fractions too and not just percentages
But also other adjectives....so can you change 'big' to another adjective?
so huge is a good idea (bit 'emotional' for IELTS!) 'a high proportion' is a good phrase ..
Yes I agree! So e.g. 'Coal was the most significant fuel in 1980 in Australia, producing 50% of electricity = very good OK?
OK nice phrase! thanks a lot <STUDENT> - I'll speak to you tomorrow about more lessons OK?
